Since 2015, our work has been dedicated to opening space to culturally and socially emerging critical topics, non-institutional and alternative curatorial and art practices, critical design, and more. With interdisciplinarity and publishing as primary work methods, PrivatePrint brings together a spectrum of collaborators, including researchers, artists, activists, designers, cultural workers, and practitioners with diverse expertise. Founded by Ilija Prokopiev and Marija Hristova, PrivatePrint operates locally and internationally with bases in Skopje (North Macedonia) and Ljubljana (Slovenia).

Proyecto Piranha is a small risograph press and cultural programming project based in Buenos Aires, Argentina. Since 2016, we have focused on collaborating with Latin American visual artists and illustrators in the publication and distribution of their work.

Rab-Rab Press is an independent publishing platform based in Helsinki. It publishes Rab-Rab: journal of political and formal inquiries in art and books combining experimental art and leftist politics with scholarly rigour and punk attitude. Initiated in 2014, Rab-Rab Press is run by Sezgin Boynik.

Radical Theory and Practice began in 2010 as an informal network of volunteers who collectively translated books in their free time, and in early 2014 it transformed into a publishing cooperative in which relationships are built horizontally and decisions are made by consensus. By publishing books about the history of liberation movements, social and environmental initiatives, alternative economic models and political prisoners, we try to inspire activists to new achievements and push our society towards social transformation. Our goal is to disseminate information as widely as possible, not to make a profit, so after some time we make our books freely available.

We are a small press located in Skagit Valley, Washington. A collaboration by Michelle Gale and Tim Hubner, with experience in editorial, book-making, and design, we publish books and zines focusing on regional authors and artists with an emphasis on women and food. We print some of our books in our studio using our Risograph GR3750. We also own a small bookstore in Edison, Washington. Book Shucker offers a carefully curated selection of books including cooking, fiction, nonfiction, small press and comics, and children’s. We prioritize carrying a diverse selection of authors and topics on our shelves and value building community through the cultural importance of books
We support people of a refugee background through art workshops, exhibitions & zines in our studio

Page Bureau 书局 is a self-publishing unit of RELATED DEPARTMENT 有关设计部门, which releases miscellaneous printed matter and digital files. RELATED DEPARTMENT 有关设计部门 is an independent graphic design practice based in Shanghai, working with a variety of design forms in response to shifting contexts of post-colonial and digital landscapes.

Reliable Copy is a publishing house and curatorial practice for works, projects, and writing by artists. Reliable Copy publishes books and documents, curates exhibitions and screenings, undertakes research projects, and hosts a wide variety of public programming. Reliable Copy is based in Bangalore, India, and was founded in 2018.

Rim Books is an artist run, artist/author focused publishing venture established in 1996 to produce and promote publications of photographic art, applied arts, art history and exhibition catalogues, that may not easily be taken on by more mainstream publishers. Their aim is to retain the original vision of the authors/artists, while providing support for editing, design and production to ensure enduring, high-quality publications, without the constraints of commercial agendas.
Helsinki based publisher of bookworks and multiples. Exploring publishing as artistic practice and publications as space for contemporary art.

Rosie’s Disobedient Press is an artist-led publishing project based in Glasgow which centres on writing from marginalised perspectives with a focus on queer, working class and feminist writers. The press is run by Lisette May Monroe and Adrien Howard and works directly with artists and writers to create unique projects on a small scale and across multiple forms, including online and printed publishing, writing, sound and live events.

Creatively applying the cultural politics of content, form, and style whilst critically dissecting these to spark literacy, Set Margins’ publications enforces the voices of marginalized cultural agendas. As a support structure, a platform for production, a network and publisher, Set Margins’ frames current impulses with particular focus for communication, forms of cooperation, and involved politics. Set Margins’ delivers critical experiences, discourse, and dialogue, steps up for liberties and builds critical community. Set Margins’ nourishes critical practices with a strong commitment to marginal voices.

Sharjah Art Foundation is an advocate, catalyst and producer of contemporary art within the Emirate of Sharjah and the surrounding region, in dialogue with the international arts community. The Foundation advances an experimental and wide-ranging programmatic model that supports the production and presentation of contemporary art, preserves and celebrates the distinct culture of the region and encourages a shared understanding of the transformational role of art. The Foundation’s core initiatives include the long-running Sharjah Biennial, featuring contemporary artists from around the world; the annual March Meeting, a convening of international arts professionals and artists; grants and residencies for artists, curators and cultural producers; ambitious and experimental commissions and a range of travelling exhibitions and scholarly publications.
Sheer Spite Press was founded in 2024 in Tiohtià:ke / Montreal to publish and distribute useful, generous, personal, political, funny, heart-filled works.

Shortt Editions creates books, prints and editions that play with, mock and appropriate cultural norms, authority and rules. The press works with a mixture of digital printing, Risograph printing and laser cutters to create unique works that manipulate the political that can be found in the everyday.

Sid Drmay is an artist, maker and freelance journalist based in KW, ON. They have a deep passion for zines and run the Hamilton Zine Machine as well as KW Zinetopia. They work in paper, plants, bioplastic and zines.

Slow Burn Books is an art book publisher and bookshop with a focus on Asia and its diaspora. Founded at the cusp of a global pandemic, Slow Burn Books launched at the NGV Melbourne Art Book Fair in 2020 and have since participated in abC Art Book Fair (China), Tokyo Art Book Fair (Japan) and PERMANENT Art Book Fair (Sydney). This small and passionate business is about connecting Melbourne’s creative communities with our regional neighbours, dedicated to making Asia-Pacific artist books and publications more accessible in Australia and vice versa. Slow Burn Books is co-founded by Nikki Lam and Scott Heinrich, who together share a passion for contemporary art, new media, design, architecture and everything in between. Nikki is a Hong Kong-born artist-curator and Scott is a designer, video director and creative producer. Together they report to Cibi, a ‘smol’ tabby cat who enjoys fabric hardcovers of art books and keeps our studio cat friendly at all times.
Smog Press is an independent photobook publisher from Los Angeles, CA. It was started in 2021 under the idea of wanting to make photobooks with our friends and heroes in intimate edition runs.

Sore Sore’s Shelf is a Jakarta-based multidisciplinary platform that creates prints and publications as a materialisation of its desire to convey the self in relation to the natural world, from its rawest sentiments to the printed matter you hold in your hands. The beauty of human experience is that every one of us has our own stories, and Sore Sore’s Shelf believes that every one of them is worth sharing to the world.

SPIN is an artist and social justice collective with a passion for publishing. We focus on collective study as a liberating practice for building community through sharing resources, skills, materials, and knowledge. This archive emerges from the necessity to care for the work done by the collective. The hegemonic structures we move through don't give the resources to archive and maintain the knowledge we produce especially when this knowledge resists those structures. Archiving, collecting and making our tools public for others is a crucial form of contestation, care and sustainability.

The studio was established in Shanghai in 2018. Creating While drinking tea. Created many series: “Waste”Story series; Honor Ancestor series; KongFu Tea series. And various creations: illustration; art toy; art installation; art zine…We don’t have a fixed style, we usually create art works in different ways, The presentation of the work is infinite.

Suburbia Projects is an architecture books retailer and publisher based out in the suburbs of Petaling Jaya. Founded in 2020 by Ashran Bahari and Naadiya Hani, Suburbia Projects aims to fill the gaps in critical and meaningful publications in architecture with a strong focus on virtues and values over aesthetics.

super professional press is an independent publishing collective in Brooklyn, NY. It publishes and features a rotating catalog of work by emerging artists in an effort to increase visibility and opportunity for anyone who wants to make zines and share them with others. With a specific focus on Risograph printing, we often make small editions of printed ephemera about oddities, humor, social justice, and pop culture in the areas of illustration, comics, photography, paper engineering, and graphic design.

SWALIF Publishing House is an independent collective based in the UAE with the goal of providing Youth in the SWANA region an avenue through which they are able to propose, produce, and propel their work into actualized projects. SWALIF Collective intends to become the main platform where aspiring, emerging writers and artists come to explore their craft and showcase their work to the world. We hope to build community and connection amongst people through bringing together art and literature by publishing books/magazines, participating in galleries, hosting exhibitions, and facilitating conversations through social media and other mediums.

We make books that are excellent, playful and affordable. All our books are by Australian artists, or collaborations between Australians and non-Australian artists. We make things somewhere between a coffee table book and a zine, we like imperfection, texture and things that feel unusual. We spend a lot of time thinking about scale, texture and making objects that delight. Tall Poppy Press operates on the lands of the Wurundjeri people of the Kulin Nation. We pay our respects to Elders past, present and emerging.

Tara Books is an independent publishing house started in 1994 by Gita Wolf. Over the years, she was joined by other creative friends who have helped Tara grow organically and in many directions. Since 2012, our home has been the Book Building in Chennai, South India. Apart from our office, it houses a bookstore, a gallery, and a residential space for visiting artists, authors and designers. We are a collective of writers, designers and book artisans who favour a non-hierarchical mode of functioning, informed by feminism and other movements for social justice. Our team at the office is currently 18 people.

te editions is a curatorial, editorial, and publishing collective operating in New York and Beijing, dedicated to exploring the intersection of art and the humanities. We examine historical and contemporary social landscapes through a diversified and microscopic lens, focusing on how cultures encounter, collapse, and transform each other within global cultural flows. In 2021, we launched the bilingual annual te magazine. Each issue draws inspiration from current events, developing a theme that encapsulates the thinking sparked by the moment. Researchers and creators from various fields are invited to contribute their work around a specific theme. In 2023, te editions was established. We consistently collaborate with research-driven artists, scholars, communities, and cultural organizations to produce physical publications together.

Established in 2021 by Amir Moghtada and Saghi Parkhideh, Tehran Zine was founded to provide young Iranian artists with the opportunity to create and publish their own Zines. Tehran Zine aims to introduce this medium, which can simply be described as “Art in the form of a booklet,” to both Iranian artists and collectors at the same time. Tehran Zine publishes two issues per year: The Special Edition, Which is a Zine created by an invited artist, and The Young Artist Edition an edition featuring works by artists who have participated in Tehran Zine’s open calls and have been selected by a jury. The published Zine will be launched and distributed by Tehran Zine. At Tehran Zine, our goal has always been to create a space for Iranian artists to explore the world of Zines. In line with this mission, we have established a rich collection of artistic Zines by both Iranian and international artists under the title of “Tehran Zine Collection.” The Tehran Zine Collection is accessible to the public by appointment or during open visit sessions, allowing enthusiasts to view a diverse range of Zines up close and become familiar with different types of Zines and their publishers. Alongside this collection, the “Tehran Zine Library” has also been established, focusing on topics such as Zine production and publishing, educational books on bookbinding techniques, book-making, artistic printing, and limited edition publishing. This library is available to artists as a valuable resource.

Temporary Press is a small publisher producing content around art and design in the form of artist books, critical texts, and everyday research, with an interest in incidental ideas and alternative practices. The press often relies on economical and improvisational design and production methods, often with a black-only Risograph and simple tools. Our books are distributed by Idea Books. The press is started by gideon-jamie, a design studio based in Singapore that develops critical responses through commissioned projects and independent work, in the form of writings, designs, and ad-hoc exhibitions and workshops. They also run Temporary Unit, an inconvenient bookshop and occasional exhibition space.

Based in Quito, Mexico City and New York, Terminal publishes books, zines and editions in collaboration with South American and Caribbean artists and curators. It's a platform exploring art within the diaspora, alternative visions of contemporary culture, resistance discourses, archives, manifestos and latinx politics, food, sound and memory.  During the COVID-19 pandemic, Terminal started the DistANSIAS project, an ever-growing series of free and downloadable "documents" by Latin American artists, activists and curators living in the continent as well as in the diaspora. Our books are in the collection of institutions like the New York City Public Library, the Centro for Puerto Rican Studies at Hunter College, Printed Matter and the Barcelona Museum of Contemporary Art (MACBA). Terminal founders / editors are Gabriela Valarezo and Jaime Nuñez del Arco.
Location: Quito, Mexico City and New York

Introduction: Thick Press is a collaboration between two old friends, a social worker (Erin Segal) and a graphic designer (Julie Cho). Inspired by utopian organizations and feminist presses, we decided to start a publishing practice organized around collaboration and care. (Both of us felt frustrated by the ways capitalism infuses design and social work practice.) We wanted to make highly visual books that account for the complexities of doing care work in the context of late capitalism and interlocking forms of oppression. We publish zine-like booklets as well as heftier titles that we distribute from our website and through Small Press Distribution. Care-givers, justice-seekers, and community-builders often find ourselves in the thick of human experience. Yet so many of the texts we produce rely on the thin logic of Western medicine and mainstream social science! What might happen if we grounded more texts in the arts? In critical theories? In spirituality? In lived experience? What might happen if we paid more attention to medium, form, and design? We aspire to a practice that is loving, reflexive, playful, and collaborative. We worry about reproducing oppressive structures, but we’re not really that interested in critique. Above all, we want to make unusual books with others. Inspired by artists’ books and zines, Thick Press publishes books that cross genres and disciplines. All our books relate to working or living in the thick of human experience.

Tofu Stand is a Berlin-based Chinese artivism collective, founded in 2024 by Chinese activists/culture practitioners who moved to Berlin from mainland China.Inspired by the early 20th-century Chinese anarchist revolutionaries in Paris who opened tofu factories as revolutionary infrastructure, Tofu Stand continues this lineage in a different time and place. Tofu Library brings together a collection of self-published books and zines from mainland China and beyond.Tofu Assemble (Events) hosts self-organised assemblies to challenge the existing modes of cultural production–consumption, and to better understand the common struggles of exiled communities in Europe.Tofu Project initiates individual and collective, short-term and long-term artivistic projects. Tofulogy, the publishing imprint of Tofu Stand, focuses on international solidarity from the situated perspectives of Chinese activists. The publications move between historical archives and the oppressive structures of the present, between fiction and non-fiction, cross historical times, geographies and communities, tracing the cracks where voices can emerge. Through this publication practice, we try to explore how different communities, from within their own positions and struggles, might carve out spaces of empathy and solidarity. Tofu Stand is a stand for self-publishing, an infrastructure for self-organising, and an attempt to bridge something in the in-betweenness. Tofu stands with Palestinians and all the oppressed, against both Western and non-Western imperial powers through creative practices.

&&& Publishing is an independent purveyor of theoretically informed, publicly engaged publications, circumventing academic/popular distinctions in order to open up a more accessible platform for public intellectual practice. As the publishing platform operated by The New Centre for Research & Practice, our aim is to shape new forms of knowledge production and circulation within and against both past and present modes of intellectual production, distribution, consumption.
Founded in 2001, Trolley Books is an independent publisher who, for nearly 25 years, has presented unique and, often, untold stories through a lot of photography, some art, and a few words.
Troublemakers Publishing is a Tokyo-based publishing studio that tells stories of misfits.

Ugly Duckling Presse is a nonprofit publisher for poetry, translation, experimental nonfiction, performance texts, and books by artists. Through the efforts of a volunteer editorial collective, UDP has published more than 400 titles to date, and produced uncounted prints and ephemera. Our publications have been recipients of the Lambda Literary Award, the Whiting Award, the Pushcart Prize, the Big Other Book Award, the Bisexual Book Award, the Firecracker Award, the Anna Rabinowitz Award, the Best Translated Book Award, and the PEN Award for Poetry in Translation. UDP favors emerging, international, and “forgotten” writers, and its books, chapbooks, artist’s books, broadsides, and periodicals often contain handmade elements, calling attention to the labor and history of bookmaking. UDP is committed to keeping its publications in circulation with our online archive of out-of-print chapbooks and our digital proofs program. In all of its activities, UDP endeavors to create an experience of art free of expectation, coercion, and utility.
Varikina Studio is micro experimental publishing studio based in Belgrade, Serbia.
Vănguard was established in 2014 as an underground transnational zine connecting and uplifting LGBTQ+ Vietnamese creatives around the world through art, literature, and activism.

A community-rooted project amplifying the voices of those too often unheard. We are looking for work by marginalised creators—BIPOC, trans*, queer, disabled, refugees and immigrants, and the working class, who speak from the edges, the intersections, and the in-betweens.

WAITHOOD Magazine is a periodical that foregrounds emerging young contemporary African artists and fugitive epistemologies to comprehend the complexities of the human experience through a maroonage perspective. The publication explores the intersection between contemporary art, the urban landscape, and the youth experience in an Africa context, to offer multiple readings of the present condition, considering not only distorted notion of past but also the role of silences, memory and nostalgia in comprehending the Black experience. The magazine is interested in contemplating imaginative processes of Black artists, writers, thinkers and makers, paying special attention to how this engage with the urban landscape to craft a future otherwise. Our curatorial practice is oriented by the desire of realising the required labour to give birth to a liberated futures.

WARAQ is an artist-led non profit organization based in Beirut, Lebanon. Founded in 2012, it is committed to the support of graphic art practices through education, research, production and publishing. Waraq has emerged over the past decade as an artist-led non-profit that redefines art publishing amid a profound cultural crisis. By merging innovative production techniques with community-driven initiatives, Waraq not only challenges traditional publishing but also creates economic opportunities, artistic empowerment, and cultural dialogue. This plan presents a roadmap for approaching larger-scale funding to expand Waraq’s unique initiatives—most notably the TABAAN! publishing platform and the Risograph Printing Facility—while amplifying its transformative impact locally and regionally. Waraq is committed to transforming the notion of publishing by integrating creative experimentation with community engagement. Its mission is to provide a platform for underrepresented voices, redefining cultural narratives in Lebanon and throughout the Arab region. By acting as both a production hub and a creative incubator, Waraq serves as a “third space” that bridges gaps between traditional artistic practices and innovative, process-driven works. The proceeds from the sales of this collection goes towards supporting our next collection of printed and digital material in collaboration with different artists, in addition to funding our Riso printing facility.

Water with Water is an experimental publishing project and visual research studio based in Doha, Qatar. We create limited-edition books, ephemera, and apparel that remix vernacular aesthetics and historical references into bold, layered visuals. Our work moves between the Gulf and global artist book scenes, blending graphic experimentation with cultural storytelling.

windpark books is an independent publishing group for contemporary art based in frankfurt am main, Yokohama and Vienna, founded in darmstadt in 2017 by leonhard fuchs, felix hofmann-wissner and jana matejka. in 2023 paul Jürgens joined the park. the publishing company is an open park for the joint development and publication of genre-fluid and independent publications that are created in close collaboration with artists, writers and scientists. during their studies, felix, jana and leo came up with the idea of founding a publishing company in may 2017 while searching for a platform for intellectual exchange and the publication of interesting works. during this time the demise of print products was already predicted in all major media. established newspapers are increasingly switching to digital subscriptions – everything gets a „plus“, „pur“ or „premium“. from america it echoes „there’s no money in books„. with a start-up capital of €80 – collected from 13 friends – jana, leo and felix set out on a dilettante saga, in spite of the economic spirit of time and against the modern windmills of late capitalism. in march 2018, the 10th publication, the (hand-bound over three days) artist book „85 tage“ by simon schmalhorst, is published. in mid-2019, windpark books expands to japan and opens a second office in yokohama. In may 2020, the 35th publication of the publishing company is released: the tape set „kudos on soundcloud“ by and with artist and musician tori kudo. the yokohama branch is closed in 2021 in search of new locations. in the first five years, windpark books has worked with 45 artists, writers and scientists on more than 40 different publications. the scope of the publications ranges from 16-page zines to 2kg photo books – from small, intimate editions to publications such as „kudos on soundcloud“ or „a beautiful party“, which were well received by an international audience. windpark books understands publications as a holistic artistic creation, so realization, production and edition are essentially based on an individual concept and therefore do not necessarily pursue an economic added value. paul, jana, leo and felix take on the position of publishers, curators and editors in their collective work. the collaborative idea, the mutual exchange of knowledge and the opportunity to gain insight into other worlds of work, life and interests is always at the core. an ideology of the printed publication as a higher medium.

Wander and Wonder Creative is an independent design and craft studio founded in 2018, with the mission to seek out underreported stories and overlooked narratives; gaining international recognition with its award-winning PLATES Magazine series, which carries four titles to date. Staying true to its founding core values of human rights, social justice, decolonisation of narratives and knowledge, and collective movement for change, the studio has since created a new range of title series as well as experimented with manual zine-making techniques, playing with everyday objects and material waste to invite readers to wander, wonder and explore beyond the pages.

Woman Cave is a design studio founded by two friends, architect Chloé Macary Carney and artist Léticia Chanliau. We have been working on notions of gender and inclusivity in inhabited spaces since 2019. We explore this theme through the publication of a bi-annual journal called Woman Journal, the setting up of participatory workshops and the realization of spaces and design objects. We also take part in exhibitions and biennials as part of cultural programs at the crossroads of contemporary art, architecture and design. We work to revitalize craft practices and DIY methods, in a spirit of transdisciplinarity and benevolence, with an emphasis on re-use.

Founded in 1974, Women’s Studio Workshop (WSW) operates and maintains an artists’ workspace that encourages the voice and vision of women, trans, intersex, nonbinary, and genderfluid artists. In addition to a robust artists’ book publishing program, artist residency, archive, and classes, WSW maintains etching, letterpress, papermaking, silkscreen, ceramics, and photography facilities.

A Bangkok-based self-publisher, zine maker and graphic designer who makes photographs to make books and zines, an artist who observes urban mundane through colours, geometric abstraction and minimalism.

Xao is a gallery, bookshop and tiny publishing house on Krymská street in Prague. Since 2016 we are organizing exhibitions, devoted to the field of illustration, graphics and book culture in general. We’re organising art workshops for children, readings, book launches. Our book case is focused on picture books and comics, including more experimental project in sometimes very small print runs. We present books and prints from Czech and foreign illustrators and comic artists, from established artists to students or interesting amateurs.

"Xaraxura" is a community space, risograph printshop and publishing in Tbilisi, Georgia. We are a small collective and publishing house made up of artists and researchers, dedicated to supporting the development of independent print culture. Alongside printing, we also organize events such as sketching meetups, talks, workshops, and film screenings. Occasionally, we sell prints and other printed materials as well. Xaraxura Press is an independent publishing space founded in 2023 by researchers, artists, and designers Giorgi Kikoria, Mariam Kakhniashvili, and Ana Mikadze. Open to the public since August 2023, Xaraxura has since grown into a collective, fostering a dynamic environment for experimental printmaking, radical publishing, and interdisciplinary collaboration. Dedicated to amplifying underrepresented artists and printed matter, the space operates as both a risography studio and a platform for small-run publications, workshops, and public programming. With a strong focus on collective knowledge-sharing, Xaraxura Press reimagines publishing as a tool for critical discourse, creative resistance, and shared authorship.

Year Zero was originally founded in Istanbul in 2019 as a magazine dedicated to exploring nascent subcultures globally. By 2023, it evolved into an independent publishing house, partnering with Rota Printing+Packaging to support contemporary storytellers in bringing their ideas to life—whether through books, magazines, community-focused events, or a blend of these formats. Year Zero’s founding spirit always remains the same, even if its nature is ever-changing: Seeking out new ideas to translate into pathways where diverse communities can connect and interact. At Year Zero, every project is a new beginning, a distinctive experiment where risk-taking converges with technical acumen. Accompanying their development from printing to distribution, we engineer dedicated ecosystems where the ideas we curate can thrive, free from conventional constraints. Year Zero exists equally in both digital and physical spaces. We are close-quarter interactions, tactile experiences, and communal gatherings. At the same time, we are an online platform where our catalog can be explored and purchased, and where upcoming publications find their testing ground.

About the Artist: Ziya Ismail is an architect and artist from India, now based in Dubai. Her art delves into the connections between nature and the human self, exploring how natural forms can mirror emotions. Her appreciation for nature's patterns began in her home state of Kerala, India, and her work focuses on the relationships between the shapes, colors and patterns in nature and their role in ecological systems.

ZONE is an independent book publisher and photography based visual arts platform run by its founder, Ali Beşikçi. Started in the summer of 2018 as a personal research project, the aim of ZONE is to cultivate a variety of dialogues between artists and their audience, as well as supporting them with printed and online publications. We make monographs, artists’ books and other collective creatures. We are drawn to works that suggest instead of showing, that whisper instead of shouting, that reach light through a deep exploration of darkness. We don’t accept any discriminatory behaviour: no racism, no fascism, no sexism, no lesbian/trans/homophobia, no support for genocides! Manifesto: Works that transcend their original statement, that give birth to different meanings, that have multiple exits or, on the contrary, end up being “cul-de-sac”s! Works that create worlds in which the audience can walk about! Works that are slow to expose themselves, that require deep reflection! Works with an idea behind! Works that inspire the audience to become “participants” instead of just “spectators”! Works that use what’s real and still create their own reality! Works that don’t try hard to make themselves pretty! Works that don’t need to “fake it” to get attention! To accept that photography is a language, with each work containing its own alphabet and dictionary! To know that an idea can be presented in more ways than one! To know that it’s possible for a work to be “unfinished”! To always be sceptical about the work!

Zontiga is a creative hub for photography enthusiasts. We publish photobooks, organize exhibitions, workshops, talks and events, and hope to inspire more individuals to embrace photography in its tangible form. Tiga Mata is a bi-annual photography zine rooted in Southeast Asia, dedicated to spotlighting the region’s vibrant and diverse photographic voices. Its name, meaning “Three Eyes” in Malay, reflects how photographers in the region often navigate the world visually, emotionally, and contextually. Each issue is built around a specific theme and is curated in collaboration with a guest editor—bringing fresh curatorial energy and deeper regional insight.
Transforming how art is created and seen in Uganda by giving artists the support they need to critically reflect our world and imagine a new one

51 Personae is a collaborative art project, publishing initiative, and cooperative platform. It started as an off-site program of the 11th Shanghai Biennale, composed of 51 events in Shanghai based on individual/group experiences/actions within the context of urban transformation (2016-17). Since 2018 onwards, it has evolved into a self-sustaining independent art publishing project, believing that publishing is both an urgent and valid artistic practice. 51 Personae places special emphasis on life experiences in Asia and the Third World, as well as marginalized voices under suppression. It collaborates with individual artists, designers, translators, collectives and self-organized social forms in Asia and beyond; exploring the contemporary forms, possibilities and potential of "realism" in art as expressive actions.
